{"conversationsMapping":{"CHAT_COMPLETION":[{"id":"a9a973c7-26e2-4472-ba43-6f1a26b51268","messages":[],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,12,27,58,76939000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,12,27,58,76957000]},{"id":"03df0785-dda4-44c0-8889-dad0e6cd823e","messages":[{"prompt":"how can i resolve this problem of build error on my buil.gradle file : following is the build output ","id":"0efc2517-ea22-4c30-927b-310e76838cb9","response":"Incorrect API key provided: sk-HSGe4***************************************4iGX. You can find your API key at https://platform.openai.com/account/api-keys."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,12,27,58,78866000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,12,27,58,527989000]},{"id":"57c53747-b48c-4754-9bd3-7506bb81ea56","messages":[{"prompt":"Build file '/Users/andrianambinina/AndroidStudioProjects/AndroidLearning/dependencyInjection/DIDemo/app/build.gradle' line: 1

A problem occurred evaluating project ':app'.
> Failed to apply plugin 'com.android.internal.application'.
 > Android Gradle plugin requires Java 11 to run. You are currently using Java 1.8.
 Your current JDK is located in /Users/andrianambinina/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/corretto-1.8.0_282/Contents/Home/jre
 You can try some of the following options:
 - changing the IDE settings.
 - changing the JAVA_HOME environment variable.
 - changing `org.gradle.java.home` in `gradle.properties`.","id":"4d5375db-3501-4caf-8611-93dccdd48993","response":"Incorrect API key provided: sk-HSGe4***************************************4iGX. You can find your API key at https://platform.openai.com/account/api-keys."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,12,28,1,688215000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,12,28,1,883989000]},{"id":"1cb313db-1dfb-497b-8d6c-cf12abc7a89b","messages":[{"prompt":"what is 1 plus 1","id":"96dc2820-1204-4f62-a986-20038093dc4e","response":"Incorrect API key provided: sk-HSGe4***************************************4iGX. You can find your API key at https://platform.openai.com/account/api-keys."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,12,29,19,468273000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,12,29,19,750639000]},{"id":"36865790-16d5-4f88-b69e-154731328e11","messages":[{"prompt":"hello","id":"e76ff77c-3da6-4e39-b413-7e3e85203e96","response":"Hello! How can I assist you today?"}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,12,33,2,912773000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,12,33,4,362237000]},{"id":"a3cc5e36-5265-4c2e-b981-65d90e248ff9","messages":[{"prompt":"how can i resolve this problem of build error on my buil.gradle file : following is the build output 
Build file '/Users/andrianambinina/AndroidStudioProjects/AndroidLearning/dependencyInjection/DIDemo/app/build.gradle' line: 1

A problem occurred evaluating project ':app'.
> Failed to apply plugin 'com.android.internal.application'.
 > Android Gradle plugin requires Java 11 to run. You are currently using Java 1.8.
 Your current JDK is located in /Users/andrianambinina/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/corretto-1.8.0_282/Contents/Home/jre
 You can try some of the following options:
 - changing the IDE settings.
 - changing the JAVA_HOME environment variable.
 - changing `org.gradle.java.home` in `gradle.properties`.","id":"6999994c-d588-49e5-b476-61fc8331694c","response":"You need to update your Java version to 11 or higher to use the Android Gradle plugin, which requires Java 11. 

Here are some options you can try:
- Update your JDK to version 11 or higher
- Change the IDE settings to point to a different version of JDK that is installed on your machine
- Update the JAVA_HOME environment variable to point to a different version of JDK that is installed on your machine
- Update the `org.gradle.java.home` property in `gradle.properties` file located in the root directory of your project to point to a different version of JDK that is installed on your machine:

```groovy
org.gradle.java.home=/path/to/jdk11
``` 

Replace `/path/to/jdk11` with the path to your JDK 11 installation directory."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,12,33,48,923058000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,12,34,0,451887000]},{"id":"9e33d3c1-dcaf-43ae-895f-cfeca3984909","messages":[{"prompt":"show me step by step how to update my JDK to version 11","id":"246f8ca6-e463-4f4f-a1b1-5a73b065f2b6","response":"Sure, here are the steps to update your JDK to version 11:

1. Download the latest version of JDK 11 from the Oracle website. 
 - Go to https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/javase-jdk11-downloads.html
 - Accept the license agreement and download the appropriate version for your operating system.

2. Install the downloaded JDK.
 - Follow the installer instructions to complete the installation.

3. Update your `PATH` environment variable.
 - Add the JDK 11 `bin` directory to your `PATH` variable. For example, if you installed JDK 11 in the default directory:
 ```
 export PATH=$PATH:/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk-11.0.9.jdk/Contents/Home/bin
 ```

4. Verify that the installation was successful by opening a command prompt/terminal and typing `java -version`. The output should show that you are running JDK 11.

That's it! You have successfully updated your JDK to version 11."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,12,36,55,530530000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,12,37,11,342567000]},{"id":"65e316d6-d14f-4663-928e-5ddd1789459e","messages":[{"prompt":"how to update my `PATH` environment variable to change it to JDK 11","id":"d9d0def2-67ba-465f-837e-73b35f096291","response":"To update the `PATH` environment variable to change it to JDK 11, follow these steps:

1. Find the location of your JDK 11 installation folder.

2. Open the System Properties dialog box by right-clicking on the "This PC" icon and selecting "Properties". Alternatively, you can press the Windows key + Pause/Break key to open the System Properties dialog box.

3. Click on the "Advanced system settings" link in the left-hand pane.

4. In the "System Properties" dialog box, click on the "Environment Variables" button.

5. In the "Environment Variables" window, under "System Variables", find the "Path" variable, and click on "Edit".

6. Add the path to your JDK 11 installation folder at the beginning of the "Variable Value" field. Separate it with a semicolon (;) from the previous entry.

7. Click "OK" to close all the windows.

Here's an example in Windows PowerShell where JDK 11 is installed in the `C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-11.0.12` folder:

```powershell
# Get current value of PATH variable
$existingPath = [Environment]::GetEnvironmentVariable("PATH", "Machine")

# Update the PATH variable to include JDK 11
$newPath = "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-11.0.12\bin;" + $existingPath
[Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable("PATH", $newPath, "Machine")
```

You will need to replace `C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-11.0.12` with the actual path to your JDK 11 installation folder."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,13,38,27,478200000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,13,38,49,17867000]},{"id":"d3c5c949-c3f7-4423-90a1-7767238eaa6f","messages":[{"prompt":"how to update my `PATH` environment variable to change it to JDK 11 on mac","id":"8c4427a1-7720-4504-8928-e5744f2a6f61","response":"You can update the `PATH` environment variable on macOS to use JDK 11 by following these steps:

1. Open Terminal (Applications -> Utilities -> Terminal)

2. Enter the command `nano ~/.bash_profile` to open your bash profile file in the nano text editor.

3. Add the following line at the end of the file to set the `PATH` variable to point to your JDK 11 installation:

 ```
 export PATH="/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk-11.0.1.jdk/Contents/Home/bin:$PATH"
 ```

 Note: Replace `/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk-11.0.1.jdk` with the path to your JDK 11 installation.

4. Press `Ctrl+X` to exit nano and save the changes.

5. Enter the command `source ~/.bash_profile` to apply the changes to your current session.

You should now be able to run `java -version` in a new Terminal window and see that it is"}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,13,39,17,918310000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,13,39,31,291242000]},{"id":"ef74fc37-82a2-4072-a621-962e4f3ee5e7","messages":[{"prompt":"how to purge cashed memorie on mac","id":"e588662c-4f1a-4c76-9786-54670bfa66fa","response":"You can purge the cached memory on a Mac by following these steps:

1. Open the Terminal application.
2. Type the following command and press Enter:
```
sudo purge
```
3. Enter your admin password when prompted and press Enter.

This will immediately purge the cached memory on your Mac. It's important to note that this process may temporarily slow down your Mac, as it frees up memory that was being used by cache files. However, your Mac should quickly resume normal operation once the purge is complete."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,13,44,18,447861000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,13,44,25,418344000]},{"id":"1a782cf9-e195-4246-a126-bdbf353e0e47","messages":[{"prompt":"give me a for mac terminal commande to find the path of Java 11 installation","id":"7e595b90-602c-4f6b-8c07-1660769acb67","response":"You can use the following command in Mac Terminal to find the path of Java 11 installation:

```bash
/usr/libexec/java_home -v 11
```

This will output the path of the Java 11 installation directory."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,13,46,18,326945000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,13,46,22,74830000]},{"id":"90e9ee56-888c-4936-938b-4d261a8e48a0","messages":[{"prompt":" how can i resolve this problem from build outputs :Apps targeting Android 12 and higher are required to specify an explicit value for `android:exported` when the corresponding component has an intent filter defined. See https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/activity-element#exported for details.","id":"e762c3a4-367e-47b0-ba96-600ff271819e","response":"Incorrect API key provided: sk-xEM0f***************************************0qIA. You can find your API key at https://platform.openai.com/account/api-keys."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,1,40,35228000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,1,40,346447000]},{"id":"7be61a51-1e1f-441e-89a0-4bed72265d85","messages":[{"prompt":"bonjour","id":"33dcfa74-a6cb-4d70-bf99-a7cf265774fc","response":"Incorrect API key provided: sk-xEM0f***************************************0qIA. You can find your API key at https://platform.openai.com/account/api-keys."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,5,11,528549000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,5,11,798049000]},{"id":"571a2fa1-336c-428d-be0b-25d0ede15c09","messages":[{"prompt":"bonjour","id":"f37b193c-a67d-4c83-869b-9732c78579fc","response":"Bonjour! Comment puis-je vous aider aujourd'hui?"}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,6,24,836056000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,6,26,585551000]},{"id":"6bd5ca09-69ee-4828-a686-888c2c46e170","messages":[{"prompt":"how to change changing the JAVA_HOME environment variable.","id":"ab8c83fa-fc67-4ccf-84b9-4e4f34999967","response":"To change the JAVA_HOME environment variable on a Unix-based system, you can follow these steps:

1. Check the current value of JAVA_HOME by running the following command in your terminal:
```bash
echo $JAVA_HOME
```

2. If JAVA_HOME is not set or you want to change it, find the path where Java is installed by running the following command in your terminal:
```bash
which java
```

3. Copy the path that is returned from the above command.

4. Open your bash configuration file (for example, `.bashrc` or `.bash_profile`) by running the following command in your terminal:
```bash
nano ~/.bashrc
```
(or `nano ~/.bash_profile`)

5. Add the following line to the end of the file:
```bash
export JAVA_HOME=/path/to/java
```
Replace "/path/to/java" with the path you copied in step 3.

6. Save the file and exit nano by pressing ctrl-x, then y, then enter.

7. Make the changes take effect by running the following command in your terminal:
```bash
source ~/.bashrc
```
(or `source ~/.bash_profile`)

8. To verify that JAVA_HOME has been updated, run the following command in your terminal:
```bash
echo $JAVA_HOME
```

On Windows, the process is similar but involves modifying the environment variables through the System Properties window."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,13,26,78560000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,13,47,737718000]},{"id":"3116e318-6cda-4704-b9af-5949bef99aa4","messages":[{"prompt":"changing the JAVA_HOME environment variable on mac","id":"ce491755-bff2-4a65-ab24-c731d24f7fcc","response":"To change the `JAVA_HOME` environment variable on Mac, follow these steps:

1. Open Terminal.
2. Type the following command to edit the `.bash_profile` file:
 ```
 nano ~/.bash_profile
 ```
3. Add the following line to the end of the file:
 ```
 export JAVA_HOME=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_291.jdk/Contents/Home
 ```
 Replace the path with the correct path to your Java installation directory.
4. Press `Ctrl + X`, then `Y`, and then `Enter` to save the changes and exit nano.
5. Type the following command to reload the `.bash_profile` file:
 ```
 source ~/.bash_profile
 ```
6. To verify that the `JAVA_HOME` variable has been set correctly, type the following command:
 ```
 echo $JAVA_HOME
 ```
 You should see the path to your Java installation directory printed out.

Note: These instructions assume that you have already installed Java on your Mac. If you haven't installed Java yet, you will need to download and install it before you can set the `JAVA_HOME` environment variable."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,13,55,915961000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,14,13,718616000]},{"id":"708eab72-0021-4406-bd26-b1099c052413","messages":[{"prompt":"how to find the path of environement variable on mac","id":"6db86d70-6ff2-48e8-879a-63e86f0b27fe","response":"You can use the `echo` command in the terminal to find the path of an environment variable on Mac. 

For example, to find the path of the `PATH` environment variable, run the following command:

```bash
echo $PATH
```

This will print out the current value of the `PATH` variable, which consists of a colon-separated list of directories that the shell searches for executable files.

If you want to find the location of a specific executable file in the `PATH`, you can use the `which` command. For example, to find the location of the `python` executable, run:

```bash
which python
```

This will print out the full path to the `python` executable file."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,33,17,902671000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,33,29,494539000]},{"id":"ba040fd2-55cd-4d2d-98ed-4d02b608e37b","messages":[{"prompt":"how to update current JDK on android studio","id":"d5477cab-bd72-44b8-96d8-1f2c52f27fbc","response":"To update the current JDK on Android Studio, you can follow these steps:

1. Open Android Studio and go to File > Project Structure.

2. In the Project Structure dialog, select SDK Location from the left-hand menu.

3. Under JDK location, click the ellipsis (...) button to navigate to the directory where your new JDK is installed.

4. Select the folder that contains your new JDK and click OK.

5. Click Apply, then OK.

Your updated JDK should now be used by Android Studio. You can verify this by going to File > Project Structure and checking the JDK location under SDK Location.

If you're using a Mac, you can also update the JDK by running the following command in Terminal:

```
export STUDIO_JDK=/path/to/your/new/jdk
```"}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,36,10,634467000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,36,23,675690000]},{"id":"7940c4df-77a9-45df-87c6-7fbc793e1e97","messages":[{"prompt":"how to update current JDK on android studio on mac","id":"5f026474-428f-4ee9-9515-33089c181ffd","response":"To update the JDK on Android Studio on Mac, follow these steps:

1. Download the latest JDK from Oracle's website.
2. Double-click on the downloaded file to install it.
3. Open Android Studio.
4. Go to "Android Studio" > "Preferences".
5. In the left-hand menu, click on "Appearance & Behavior" then "System Settings" and then "Android SDK".
6. Click on the "SDK Tools" tab.
7. Check the box next to "Show Package Details".
8. Look for "JDK" in the list of packages and check its checkbox.
9. Click "Apply" and then "OK".

Now, Android Studio will be using the latest version of the JDK."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,36,41,832848000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,36,53,288473000]},{"id":"40ab4edc-04a1-45fe-8d5c-8e8f3e4a57b8","messages":[{"prompt":"how to resolve the following problem from buid output: 
The Android Gradle plugin supports only kotlin-android-extensions Gradle plugin version 1.6.20 and higher.
The following dependencies do not satisfy the required version:
root project 'DIDemo' -> org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-gradle-plugin:1.5.21","id":"3c082bdd-77e0-4a4a-ae2c-7b0f08663126","response":"To resolve this problem, you need to update the `kotlin-android-extensions` Gradle plugin version to 1.6.20 or higher in your `build.gradle` file.

Add the following code snippet to the `build.gradle` file in the `dependencies` section:

```
dependencies {
 classpath "org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-gradle-plugin:1.6.20"
}
```

After updating the `kotlin-gradle-plugin` dependency, run the build again to ensure that the issue is resolved."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,45,39,447134000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,45,48,51706000]},{"id":"0abe1390-a3d7-4ed9-a2bf-af67d5641b04","messages":[{"prompt":"how to resolve this problem : Manifest merger failed : android:exported needs to be explicitly specified for element <activity#com.anushka.didemo.MainActivity>. Apps targeting Android 12 and higher are required to specify an explicit value for `android:exported` when the corresponding component has an intent filter defined. See https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/activity-element#exported for details.","id":"5e61ee20-a3a0-40b2-87aa-ac177531cae8","response":"This error occurs when the `android:exported` attribute is not specified for an activity in the AndroidManifest.xml file, and the app is targeting Android 12 or higher.

To resolve this error, you need to explicitly specify the `android:exported` attribute for the MainActivity in your AndroidManifest.xml file. Set the value to `true` or `false` based on your needs.

Here's an example:
```xml
<activity android:name=".MainActivity"
 android:exported="true">
 <intent-filter>
 <action android:name="android.intent.action.MAIN" />
 <category android:name="android.intent.category.LAUNCHER" />
 </intent-filter>
</activity>
```

Note that if you set the `android:exported` attribute to `true`, it means that the activity can be accessed by other apps. It's important to understand the implications of this and make sure that it's necessary for your app."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,51,53,724528000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,52,8,529619000]}]}}

option.name: currentConversation
option.value:
{"id":"0abe1390-a3d7-4ed9-a2bf-af67d5641b04","messages":[{"prompt":"how to resolve this problem : Manifest merger failed : android:exported needs to be explicitly specified for element <activity#com.anushka.didemo.MainActivity>. Apps targeting Android 12 and higher are required to specify an explicit value for `android:exported` when the corresponding component has an intent filter defined. See https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/activity-element#exported for details.","id":"5e61ee20-a3a0-40b2-87aa-ac177531cae8","response":"This error occurs when the `android:exported` attribute is not specified for an activity in the AndroidManifest.xml file, and the app is targeting Android 12 or higher.

To resolve this error, you need to explicitly specify the `android:exported` attribute for the MainActivity in your AndroidManifest.xml file. Set the value to `true` or `false` based on your needs.

Here's an example:
```xml
<activity android:name=".MainActivity"
 android:exported="true">
 <intent-filter>
 <action android:name="android.intent.action.MAIN" />
 <category android:name="android.intent.category.LAUNCHER" />
 </intent-filter>
</activity>
```

Note that if you set the `android:exported` attribute to `true`, it means that the activity can be accessed by other apps. It's important to understand the implications of this and make sure that it's necessary for your app."}],"clientCode":"CHAT_COMPLETION","model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","createdOn":[2023,4,15,14,51,53,724528000],"updatedOn":[2023,4,15,14,52,8,529619000]}
